courseDescription: Approval for enrollment and allowable credit is determined by the Business Analytics CAP advisor and the Career Development Services in the semester prior to enrollment.

The course examines international freight transportation and terms for movement of international trade.  It discusses processes and concepts involved in international ocean and intermodal transportation.  It shows how shipping companies enter into foreign markets and participate in international trade.  It also covers operational issues such as payment, commercial documents, insurance; customs and clearance; shipping organizations and societies, and shipping law.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of terms for movement of international trade
Familiarity with international ocean and intermodal transportation
Understanding of commercial documents and insurance procedures
Knowledge of customs and clearance processes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Negotiation skills for entering foreign markets
Interaction with shipping organizations and societies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of shipping organizations structure and leadership

courseDescription: An overview of international and U.S. initiatives to ensure the security of vessels, cargo, people, and infrastructure within the maritime domain.  In addition to the impacts of regulatory requirements on maritime commerce, the course also addresses maritime threats to the international economy (including maritime piracy and maritime terrorism), maritime coalitions, and state-of-the-art techniques and tools for safeguarding ocean-borne commerce.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of tools for safeguarding ocean-borne commerce
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Strategic planning to mitigate maritime threats
Critical evaluation of maritime security initiatives

courseDescription: An overview of the strategic sourcing of materials and services in the organization and its role in the supply chain.  Topics include sourcing decisions, price/cost analysis, quality issues, purchasing, supplier selection, legal and ethical issues, third party logistics, freight forwarding, and acquisition of services and capital assets.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of third-party logistics and freight forwarding
Acquisition of services and capital assets
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Legal and ethical decision making in sourcing
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning for sourcing and purchasing
Managing legal and ethical issues in sourcing

courseDescription: This course examines the application of quality principles to the management of manufacturing and service organizations.  Topics include fundamentals of quality management, Six Sigma, statistical process control, process capability and reliability.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of process capability and reliability
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex manufacturing and service processes

courseDescription: Supply chain management integrates all activities associated with the flow of materials and information from product start to customers.  Examples include order processing, warehousing, inventory management, transportation and logistics, and the costs and information systems supporting these activities.  Particular application is made to global logistics systems supporting port and maritime activities.  Supply chain relationships can be improved through effective integration of management and via such technologies as the World Wide Web, electronic data exchange, and enterprise resource planning (ERP).  (cross-listed with BNAL 441)
Technical and Digital Skills: Usage of World Wide Web technologies for supply chain management
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication for integration of management
Collaboration to improve supply chain relationships
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing information systems supporting logistical activities

courseDescription: An introduction to the fundamentals of cargo, hull, protection and indemnity insurance. Topics include insurance markets, agents, underwriters, forms of policies, valuation, Total Loss, Particular Average, General Average, insured perils, war risks, subrogation, reinsurance and insurers of pollution liabilities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of cargo, hull, protection and indemnity insurance
Knowledge of insurance markets, agents, underwriters
Understanding of valuation, Total Loss, Particular Average, General Average
Insight into insured perils, war risks
Knowledge of insurers of pollution liabilities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with insurance agents and underwriters
Negotiation skills for policy terms and conditions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of insurance policies and their terms

courseTitle: Distribution Center and Material Handling Management
courseDescription: This course is designed to investigate the strategic role of distribution center and material management in the supply chain. Course content includes the analysis of distribution center operations through the study of design, system selection, and layout configuration as well as the evaluation of material handling and inventory management options.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Strategic analysis of distribution center operations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and managing distribution center operations

courseDescription: Examines the management of freight shipping organizations involved in the transport of cargo by ship. Key topics are managing ships and ship space; shipping markets, operations, costs, investment, insurance, claims, and regulation; and ship types, cargoes, safety, flagging, pollution, and chartering and purchase.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of ship types and cargoes
Understanding of pollution issues in shipping
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with various stakeholders in the shipping industry
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning for investments and operations

courseDescription: Examines the management of seaports in the movement of cargo throughput. It presents concepts related to design, organization, administration, and operation of ports. It discusses issues involved in planning, investment, communication systems, congestion, pollution, safety, security; intermodal transportation; water and land accessibility; and port competition and cooperation to improve customer service.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of communication systems within ports
Knowledge of water and land accessibility
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Strategizing for port competition and cooperation

courseDescription: This course is designed to explore and analyze the current condition of inland waterways both throughout the United States and around the globe with an emphasis on the creation of intermodal transportation networks.  It will include an overview of existing infrastructure as well as financing mechanisms, national and international competitive strategies, risk management (public safety and emergency preparedness), and the environmental benefits as well as consider current legislation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of environmental benefits of intermodal transportation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of national and international competitive strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning for intermodal transportation networks

courseTitle: Entrepreneurship in Maritime and Supply Chain Management
courseDescription: This course is designed to help students enhance their personal and professional development through innovation guided by faculty members and professionals. The course offers students an opportunity to integrate disciplinary theory and knowledge through developing a supply chain process, product, business, or other initiative. The real-world experiences that entrepreneurships provide will help students understand how academic knowledge leads to transformations, innovations, and solutions to different types of problems.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with professionals and faculty members
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Development of practical solutions for real-world problems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and managing new business initiatives

courseTitle: Topics in Maritime and Supply Chain Management
courseDescription: A study of selected topics within Maritime and Supply Chain Management designed to provide an in-depth exploration of current issues.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of supply chain management software
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Cross-cultural communication in global supply chains
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational skills in supply chain management

courseDescription: Affords students the opportunity to undertake independent study under the direction of a faculty member.

An overview of the strategic sourcing of materials and services in the organization and its role in the supply chain. Topics include sourcing decisions, price/cost analysis, quality issues, purchasing, supplier selection, legal and ethical issues, third party logistics, freight forwarding, and acquisition of services and capital assets.
Technical and Digital Skills: Legal compliance in sourcing and purchasing
Procurement of services and capital assets
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interdepartmental coordination for sourcing and purchasing
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in sourcing and purchasing processes

courseTitle: Distribution Center and Material Handling Management
courseDescription: This course is designed to investigate the strategic role of distribution center and material management in the supply chain. Course content includes the analysis of distribution center operations through the study of design, system selection, and layout configuration as well as the evaluation of material handling and inventory management options.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Strategic analysis of distribution and material management in supply chain
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic role of distribution center in supply chain

courseTitle: Topics in Maritime and Supply Chain Management
courseDescription: A study of selected topics within maritime and supply chain management designed to provide an in-depth exploration of current issues.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis in maritime and supply chain contexts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication within a supply chain
Negotiation skills in supply chain context
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership within maritime and supply chain teams
Project management in maritime and supply chain contexts

courseTitle: International Shipping and Supply Chain Management
courseDescription: Examines international freight transportation and terms for movement of international trade; focuses on improving supply chain relationships in the movement of international trade/directing the flow of information, materials and products.  (cross-listed with PORT 610)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of terms for movement of international trade
Directing information, materials and products flow
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with international trade partners
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and resolution of supply chain issues
Analytical thinking in international trade context
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in directing flow of information, materials and products

courseDescription: An overview of international and U.S initiatives to ensure the security of vessels, cargo, people, and infrastructure within the maritime domain. In addition to the impacts of regulatory requirements on maritime commerce, the course also addresses maritime threats to the international economy (including maritime piracy and maritime terrorism), maritime coalitions , and state-of-the-art techniques and tools for safeguarding ocean0borne commerce. (cross-listed with PORT 615)
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with tools and techniques for safeguarding ocean-borne commerce
Knowledge of international and U.S initiatives related to maritime security
Awareness of state-of-the-art maritime security techniques
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate security threats and risks
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the impact of regulatory requirements on maritime commerce

courseDescription: This course explores the theoretical foundations of global supply chain partnerships and reverse logistics systems, and examines the practices, risks, and opportunities found in today's systems.  Fundamental tools and techniques are used to provide insights and solutions on how to best organize, manage, and optimize such systems to achieve sustainable performance. (cross-listed with PORT 616)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of global supply chain partnerships
Application of fundamental tools and techniques for system optimization

courseDescription: The course includes a review of the key elements of transportation such as: modes of transportation, transportation economics, and transportation technology and regulations.   The relationships between intermediaries, carriers and shippers are discussed, as well as company roles and operations within the transportation field, transportation sourcing and management, and transportation risk management.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with different modes of transportation
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Relationship management with intermediaries, carriers and shippers
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding company roles and operations within the transportation field

courseDescription: An overview of the strategic sourcing of materials and services in the organization and its role in the supply chain. Emphasis is placed on effectively managing the supply management process. Topics include the analysis of sourcing decisions, price/cost analysis, purchasing, supplier selection and relationship management, legal and ethical issues, third party logistics, freight forwarding, and acquisition of services and capital assets.

Supply chain management integrates all activities associated with the flows of materials, information, and funds.  Examples include strategic sourcing, order processing, warehousing, inventory management, transportation and logistics, and the costs and information systems supporting these activities.

This course investigates the strategic role of distribution centers in the supply chain. Course content includes the analysis of distribution center operations through the study of design, system selection, and layout configuration as well as the evaluation of material handling and inventory management alternatives. Tactical, operational and strategic planning options are also discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Selection and configuration of system layouts
Evaluation of material handling and inventory management alternatives

courseDescription: This course examines how supply chain management and information technology integrate to support global e-commerce opportunities.  Topics include the theories and practices of material flow management, omnichannel distribution and retailing, maritime, logistics, procurement, and inventory management.
